Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Vermont stands at a crossroads on criminal justice reform: do we transform how we respond to social problems and crime by investing in people to achieve safer, healthier communities, or do we continue the same misguided approaches that have profoundly negative impacts on our state?

This choice is highlighted in recent proposals to close Vermont’s only women’s prison, Chittenden Regional Correctional Facility (CRCF). Conditions in the facility are deplorable and a high proportion of the women arrive there with extensive histories of trauma and abuse. Many of the women are primary caregivers for dependent children – leaving a whole generation of children without a parent for much of their childhood.

Advocates have said for years that most of the women in CRCF should be in halfway homes or step-down facilities, which would better address the root causes of incarceration and help to heal, instead of compound, the trauma they’ve experienced. Unfortunately, our legislature is poised to reject that option. H.543 — passed by the House, now pending in the Senate — allocates $250,000 to study replacing CRCF with a “new correctional facility” either as a separate facility or as part of a prison “campus.”

If we’re going to build healthier communities, legislators first need to focus on alternatives to incarceration and reducing our prison population, not on building more prisons. Contact your state senators today and urge them to reject funding for new prisons.

Take Action

H.543 doesn’t mention any of the available options Vermont should prioritize — prevention and treatment programs, transitional housing, job training, and other less costly, more effective investments — the alternatives Vermont taxpayers want to see before spending vast sums of money on prison construction.

Tell your state senators to oppose funding for new prisons and instead prioritize reducing incarceration and increasing the use of alternatives.

Thanks for sticking with us,

James Lyall
Executive Director, ACLU of Vermont
